article_title: Has Abbott forgotten that he once challenged insurer to live up to charitable mission?
article_text:
Has Abbott forgotten that he once challenged insurer to live up to charitable mission?

Photo: SAUL LOEB, Staff Gov. Greg Abbott's office blamed the federal government for the... In November, Liz Furman, a Sugar Land CPA whose PPO insurance policy had been terminated, wrote Texas Gov. Greg Abbott for help.

article_metadata.description: The Texas Blue, which operates as a "nonprofit," claimed it lost money on PPOs last year, despite the fact that Illinois-based parent company Health Care Service Corp. brought in nearly $28 billion in revenue, gave its CEO a $10 million bonus and sat on $10 billion in reserves, according to financial statements.  The response, on Nov. 23, was disappointing and surprisingly passive for a governor who has ordered investigations on everybody from Planned Parenthood to U.S. soldiers participating in the Jade Helm training exercise.  Abbott's office blamed the federal government for Furman's "unfortunate" situation, railed against Obamacare and declared the governor of Texas powerless to do anything.  "Governor Abbott ultimately cannot intervene in the affairs of insurance companies, which are private businesses," the letter read.  Abbott, whose solicitor general at the time was none other than U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz, objected to the Texas Blue's 1998 merger with the Illinois corporation because it cheated Texans, effectively transferring "charitable assets out of a Texas charitable nonprofit corporation," according to court records.  If the Texas Blue was held on appeal to be a charitable corporation, the company that bought it agreed to pay an estimated $560 million to health-related charities benefitting Texans.  [...] the court of appeals in Austin ruled against Abbott, a decision that ran counter to other courts across the country, which were awarding states a share of Blue Cross assets amid mergers.  When Abbott appealed to the Texas Supreme Court, attorneys general of 17 other states submitted a friend of the court brief detailing a national pattern of courts ruling in favor of protecting Blue Cross assets under charitable principles.  The lower court had reached its opinion in part by determining the Legislature couldn't have meant what it said in using the word "charitable" and in part by defining charity strictly according to the tax code.
article_metadata.author.name: By Lisa Falkenberg
